title: Dems press for election protection after Mueller indictment
authors: Elana Schor, Michael Crowley, Louis Nelson
content:
The mammoth indictment issued by special counsel Robert Mueller on Friday sparked a wave of Democratic calls to shield November ’ s midterm vote from foreign interference — but only scattered GOP demands for stronger safeguards .
The divided response to the charges against 13 Russian nationals for a long-running , well-funded bid to influence the 2016 election underscores lawmakers ’ difficulty in agreeing on any legislation to counter Moscow ’ s disruption campaign .
Bipartisan proposals to bolster election cybersecurity and toughen disclosure rules for online political ads have yet to gain momentum in the GOP-controlled Congress . And lately , Democrats have focused more on pushing President Donald Trump on Russia sanctions that his administration chose not to impose last month .
Still , numerous Democrats seized on the indictment , with Sen. Richard Blumenthal ( D-Conn. ) lamenting that Trump “ denies reality ” by minimizing Russia ’ s offensives and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi ( D-Calif. ) slamming Trump for presenting no “ strategic plan to confront the Russians . ”
Trump greeted Mueller ’ s move with a tweet acknowledging the existence of Russian interference efforts he once dismissed as a “ hoax , ” while insisting that Kremlin-backed plans to boost his prospects did not affect the election ’ s outcome . In fact , the indictment offered no judgment on whether Russia ’ s efforts skewed the election , as Sen. Jeff Flake ( R-Ariz. ) joined Democrats in pointing out on Friday .

“ It was clear it was directed in favor of one candidate . Whether it was dispositive or not , that ’ s still a question , ” Flake said of Russian meddling efforts in an interview . “ But there ’ s going to be a lot more pressure on the administration to actually move on this . ”
Whether that pressure will lead to actual results remains an open question . Since this Congress began , Republican leaders have looked to their intelligence committees to conduct investigations that would inform future legislation , with mixed results .
The Senate ’ s probe remains on a bipartisan track , with Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr ( R-N.C. ) and Vice Chairman Mark Warner ( D-Va. ) eyeing initial recommendations on election security as soon as this month . Their House counterparts , however , have become mired in partisan warfare over a GOP memo alleging misconduct at the FBI in its investigation of the Trump camp ’ s ties to Russia .
Speaker Paul Ryan ( R-Wis. ) responded to the Mueller indictment with a statement referencing the intelligence panel ’ s ongoing work , saying that “ we need to follow the facts and work to protect the integrity of future elections. ” But House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes ’ ( R-Calif. ) made no mention of future legislative action to prevent what Trump ’ s own CIA director identified was a likely Russian effort to influence November ’ s congressional contests .
Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer put the onus on the White House to act against Russian meddling , pushing the administration to “ alert the American public any time the Russians attempt to interfere. ” The New York Democrat also pushed Trump to move ahead with the sanctions against Moscow that Congress called for in a bipartisan bill that passed overwhelmingly last year .
The sanctions have recently become more of a partisan concern , with Republicans giving the Trump administration more room to execute a diplomatic strategy that relies on using the threat of penalties as a deterrent against Russian President Vladimir Putin ’ s government .
Among the bipartisan options before Congress is a social-media ad disclosure bill backed by Sens . Amy Klobuchar ( D-Minn. ) and John McCain ( R-Ariz. ) as well as Warner . Klobuchar on Friday issued a pointed query to Facebook , Twitter and other online giants leery of new regulations : “ Will 13 indictments get the big social media companies to stop opposing my bill to require disclosure and disclaimers on political ads ? ” she tweeted .
Klobuchar is also a leading backer of a bipartisan proposal to help state election officials beef up their cyber-defenses ahead of this year ’ s elections . That effort has three Senate GOP backers — James Lankford of Oklahoma , Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Susan Collins of Maine — but no obvious path to the floor in the coming weeks . A similar proposal failed to get a vote last year during debate over the annual defense authorization bill .
Lankford joined Flake on Friday in treating the Mueller indictment as a nudge to shield future elections from Russian disruption . “ They will try again , and we must be ready , ” he said in a statement .
Among the handful of fellow Republicans warning about Moscow ’ s interference was Sen. Ben Sasse of Nebraska .
“ This ought to be a wake-up call to Washington : Putin ’ s shadow war is aimed at undermining Americans ’ trust in our institutions , ” Sasse said in a statement Friday . We know Russia is coming back in 2018 and 2020 – we have to take this threat seriously . ”
content_original:
The mammoth indictment issued by special counsel Robert Mueller on Friday sparked a wave of Democratic calls to shield November’s midterm vote from foreign interference — but only scattered GOP demands for stronger safeguards.

The divided response to the charges against 13 Russian nationals for a long-running, well-funded bid to influence the 2016 election underscores lawmakers’ difficulty in agreeing on any legislation to counter Moscow’s disruption campaign.

Bipartisan proposals to bolster election cybersecurity and toughen disclosure rules for online political ads have yet to gain momentum in the GOP-controlled Congress. And lately, Democrats have focused more on pushing President Donald Trump on Russia sanctions that his administration chose not to impose last month.

Still, numerous Democrats seized on the indictment, with Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) lamenting that Trump “denies reality” by minimizing Russia’s offensives and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) slamming Trump for presenting no “strategic plan to confront the Russians.”

Trump greeted Mueller’s move with a tweet acknowledging the existence of Russian interference efforts he once dismissed as a “hoax,” while insisting that Kremlin-backed plans to boost his prospects did not affect the election’s outcome. In fact, the indictment offered no judgment on whether Russia’s efforts skewed the election, as Sen. Jeff Flake (R-Ariz.) joined Democrats in pointing out on Friday.

“It was clear it was directed in favor of one candidate. Whether it was dispositive or not, that’s still a question,” Flake said of Russian meddling efforts in an interview. “But there’s going to be a lot more pressure on the administration to actually move on this.”

Whether that pressure will lead to actual results remains an open question. Since this Congress began, Republican leaders have looked to their intelligence committees to conduct investigations that would inform future legislation, with mixed results.

The Senate’s probe remains on a bipartisan track, with Intelligence Committee Chairman Richard Burr (R-N.C.) and Vice Chairman Mark Warner (D-Va.) eyeing initial recommendations on election security as soon as this month. Their House counterparts, however, have become mired in partisan warfare over a GOP memo alleging misconduct at the FBI in its investigation of the Trump camp’s ties to Russia.

Speaker Paul Ryan (R-Wis.) responded to the Mueller indictment with a statement referencing the intelligence panel’s ongoing work, saying that “we need to follow the facts and work to protect the integrity of future elections.” But House Intelligence Committee Chairman Devin Nunes’ (R-Calif.) made no mention of future legislative action to prevent what Trump’s own CIA director identified was a likely Russian effort to influence November’s congressional contests.

Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer put the onus on the White House to act against Russian meddling, pushing the administration to “alert the American public any time the Russians attempt to interfere.” The New York Democrat also pushed Trump to move ahead with the sanctions against Moscow that Congress called for in a bipartisan bill that passed overwhelmingly last year.

The sanctions have recently become more of a partisan concern, with Republicans giving the Trump administration more room to execute a diplomatic strategy that relies on using the threat of penalties as a deterrent against Russian President Vladimir Putin’s government.

Among the bipartisan options before Congress is a social-media ad disclosure bill backed by Sens. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minn.) and John McCain (R-Ariz.) as well as Warner. Klobuchar on Friday issued a pointed query to Facebook, Twitter and other online giants leery of new regulations: “Will 13 indictments get the big social media companies to stop opposing my bill to require disclosure and disclaimers on political ads?” she tweeted.

Klobuchar is also a leading backer of a bipartisan proposal to help state election officials beef up their cyber-defenses ahead of this year’s elections. That effort has three Senate GOP backers — James Lankford of Oklahoma, Lindsey Graham of South Carolina and Susan Collins of Maine — but no obvious path to the floor in the coming weeks. A similar proposal failed to get a vote last year during debate over the annual defense authorization bill.

Lankford joined Flake on Friday in treating the Mueller indictment as a nudge to shield future elections from Russian disruption. “They will try again, and we must be ready,” he said in a statement.

Among the handful of fellow Republicans warning about Moscow’s interference was Sen. Ben Sasse of Nebraska.

“This ought to be a wake-up call to Washington: Putin’s shadow war is aimed at undermining Americans’ trust in our institutions,” Sasse said in a statement Friday. We know Russia is coming back in 2018 and 2020 – we have to take this threat seriously.”

Burgess Everett contributed to this report.
